rev.comment: /* 2012 politics and potential presidential candidacy */ this quote doesn't really fit in this section-- moved it upward.
rev.diff:
Line 172: Line 172:
===2012 politics and potential presidential candidacy ===
===2012 politics and potential presidential candidacy ===
In 2010, Trump said he considered himself a potential candidate for [[President of the United States]] in [[United States presidential election, 2012|the 2012 election]].<ref>Madison, Lucy (October 4, 2010) [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20018405-503544.html "Donald Trump for President in 2012?"], CBS News. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref><ref>Zwick, Jesse (October 4, 2010) [http://washingtonindependent.com/99472/donald-trump-for-president "Donald Trump for President?"], The Washington Independent. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref> In his [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|primary campaign]], Trump has made a February speech to a [[Conservative Political Action Conference|CPAC]] gathering,<ref name="thall11">{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/tipsheet/katiepavlich/2011/02/10/crowd_goes_wild_over_donald_trump_speech_at_cpac|title=Crowd Goes Wild Over Donald Trump Speech at CPAC|publisher=[[Townhall.com]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> an early venue for candidates considering a presidential run, as a write-in candidate in its [[straw poll]] for the office. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released in March 2011 found Donald Trump leading among potential contenders for the Republican nomination for President of the United States, one point ahead of former Massachusetts Governor [[Mitt Romney]].<ref>Haberman, Maggie (March 7, 2011).[http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/politics/Trump_tops_Romney__Pawlenty-117496043.html Trump tops Romney, Pawlenty]. ''NBC New York''. Retrieved March 7, 2011.</ref> A Newsweek poll conducted February 2011 showed Trump within a few points of Obama, with many voters undecided in the November 2012 general election for President of the United States against [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-02-21/obama-hits-50-percent-approval-rating-according-to-new-newsweekdaily-beast-poll/?cid=hp:beastoriginalsL2|title=Obama Hits 50 Percent Approval Rating, According to New Newsweek/Daily Beast Poll|publisher=The Newsweek / Daily Beast Company LLC|first=Douglas|last=Schoen|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref> A poll released in April 2011 by Public Policy Polling showed Trump having a nine point lead in a potential contest for the Republican nomination for President of the United States.<ref>Shadid, Aliyah (April 15, 2011).[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/04/15/2011-04-15_donald_trump_takes_lead_in_gop_primary_poll_beats_romney_huckabee_palin_gingrich.html?r=news/politics Donald Trump takes lead in GOP primary poll, beats Romney, Huckabee, Palin, Gingrich, Bachmann, Paul].''New York Daily News''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref> A poll conducted on May 10, 2011, showed Trump tied for fifth place with Ron Paul among Republicans.<ref> [http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/PPP_Release_US_0510925.pdf Public Policy Polling]</ref>
In 2010, Trump said he considered himself a potential candidate for [[President of the United States]] in [[United States presidential election, 2012|the 2012 election]].<ref>Madison, Lucy (October 4, 2010) [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20018405-503544.html "Donald Trump for President in 2012?"], CBS News. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref><ref>Zwick, Jesse (October 4, 2010) [http://washingtonindependent.com/99472/donald-trump-for-president "Donald Trump for President?"], The Washington Independent. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref> In his [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|primary campaign]], Trump has made a February speech to a [[Conservative Political Action Conference|CPAC]] gathering,<ref name="thall11">{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/tipsheet/katiepavlich/2011/02/10/crowd_goes_wild_over_donald_trump_speech_at_cpac|title=Crowd Goes Wild Over Donald Trump Speech at CPAC|publisher=[[Townhall.com]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> an early venue for candidates considering a presidential run, as a write-in candidate in its [[straw poll]] for the office. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released in March 2011 found Donald Trump leading among potential contenders for the Republican nomination for President of the United States, one point ahead of former Massachusetts Governor [[Mitt Romney]].<ref>Haberman, Maggie (March 7, 2011).[http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/politics/Trump_tops_Romney__Pawlenty-117496043.html Trump tops Romney, Pawlenty]. ''NBC New York''. Retrieved March 7, 2011.</ref> A Newsweek poll conducted February 2011 showed Trump within a few points of Obama, with many voters undecided in the November 2012 general election for President of the United States against [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-02-21/obama-hits-50-percent-approval-rating-according-to-new-newsweekdaily-beast-poll/?cid=hp:beastoriginalsL2|title=Obama Hits 50 Percent Approval Rating, According to New Newsweek/Daily Beast Poll|publisher=The Newsweek / Daily Beast Company LLC|first=Douglas|last=Schoen|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref> A poll released in April 2011 by Public Policy Polling showed Trump having a nine point lead in a potential contest for the Republican nomination for President of the United States.<ref>Shadid, Aliyah (April 15, 2011).[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/04/15/2011-04-15_donald_trump_takes_lead_in_gop_primary_poll_beats_romney_huckabee_palin_gingrich.html?r=news/politics Donald Trump takes lead in GOP primary poll, beats Romney, Huckabee, Palin, Gingrich, Bachmann, Paul].''New York Daily News''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref> A poll conducted on May 10, 2011, showed Trump tied for fifth place with Ron Paul among Republicans.<ref> [http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/PPP_Release_US_0510925.pdf Public Policy Polling]</ref>
  +   +
Speaking to an audience in Boca Raton, Florida on April 16, 2011, Trump said that voter reaction to [[George W. Bush]]'s performance as U.S. President was the cause for the election of his successor, [[Barack Obama]], and further that Obama would probably be known as the worst president in U.S. history.<ref>[http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/april/233988/Donald-Trump:-Obama-will-go-down-as-worst-president-in-U.S.-history Donald Trump: Obama will go down as worst president in U.S. history].''Bright House Networks''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref>
Trump's present political stances include the following:<ref>{{cite web|author=Nikki Schwab and Katy Adams |url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/blogs/yeas-nays/2011/02/trump-makes-case-oval-office-upsets-paul-supporters |title=Trump makes a case for the Oval Office, upsets Paul supporters | Nikki Schwab | Yeas & Nays |publisher=Washington Examiner |date= |accessdate=2011-04-21}}</ref>
Trump's present political stances include the following:<ref>{{cite web|author=Nikki Schwab and Katy Adams |url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/blogs/yeas-nays/2011/02/trump-makes-case-oval-office-upsets-paul-supporters |title=Trump makes a case for the Oval Office, upsets Paul supporters | Nikki Schwab | Yeas & Nays |publisher=Washington Examiner |date= |accessdate=2011-04-21}}</ref>
Line 190: Line 192:
On May 5, 2011, Trump announced he would not be the celebrity pace-car driver for the 2011 [[Indianapolis 500|Indy 500]] as was previously announced a month earlier by the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] (on April 5, 2011.)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/indycar/2011-05-05-trump-indy500_N.htm|title=Donald Trump bows out of Indy 500; won't drive pace car|author=Curt Cavin|coauthor=Dan McFeely|work=Indianapolis Star|published by = USA Today|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianapolismotorspeedway.com/default/news/show/42166-global-icon-trump-to-drive-100th-anniversary-indianapolis-500-pace-car/|title=Global Icon Trump To Drive 100th Anniversary Indianapolis 500 Pace Car|author=Paul Kelly|work=Indianapolis Motor Speedway|date=April 5, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref> Trump stated he made the decision because of business constraints, but there had been a fan campaign for the Speedway to instead name a racing celebrity to the position<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indystar.com/article/20110504/ENTERTAINMENT/105040329/Campaign-grows-set-early-bump-day-Trump?odyssey=tab|topnews|text|Sports|title=Campaign grows to set early bump day for Trump|author=Dan McFeely|work=Indianapolis Star|date= May 4, 2011|accessdate= May 11, 2011}}</ref> and a Speedway press release stated that Trump cancelled because of his intention to run for President.<ref>{{cite news|author=Weir, Tom|title=Donald Trump bows out of Indy 500 pace car role|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2011/05/donald-trump-bows-out-of-indy-500-pace-car-role/1|date=May 5, 2011|work=USA Today|publisher=Gannett|accessdate=May 7, 2011}}</ref>
On May 5, 2011, Trump announced he would not be the celebrity pace-car driver for the 2011 [[Indianapolis 500|Indy 500]] as was previously announced a month earlier by the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] (on April 5, 2011.)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/indycar/2011-05-05-trump-indy500_N.htm|title=Donald Trump bows out of Indy 500; won't drive pace car|author=Curt Cavin|coauthor=Dan McFeely|work=Indianapolis Star|published by = USA Today|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianapolismotorspeedway.com/default/news/show/42166-global-icon-trump-to-drive-100th-anniversary-indianapolis-500-pace-car/|title=Global Icon Trump To Drive 100th Anniversary Indianapolis 500 Pace Car|author=Paul Kelly|work=Indianapolis Motor Speedway|date=April 5, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref> Trump stated he made the decision because of business constraints, but there had been a fan campaign for the Speedway to instead name a racing celebrity to the position<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indystar.com/article/20110504/ENTERTAINMENT/105040329/Campaign-grows-set-early-bump-day-Trump?odyssey=tab|topnews|text|Sports|title=Campaign grows to set early bump day for Trump|author=Dan McFeely|work=Indianapolis Star|date= May 4, 2011|accessdate= May 11, 2011}}</ref> and a Speedway press release stated that Trump cancelled because of his intention to run for President.<ref>{{cite news|author=Weir, Tom|title=Donald Trump bows out of Indy 500 pace car role|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2011/05/donald-trump-bows-out-of-indy-500-pace-car-role/1|date=May 5, 2011|work=USA Today|publisher=Gannett|accessdate=May 7, 2011}}</ref>
â
====Statements regarding President Obama and George W. Bush====
+
====Statements regarding President Obama====
â
Speaking to an audience in Boca Raton, Florida on April 16, 2011, Trump said that voter reaction to [[George W. Bush]]'s performance as U.S. President was the cause for the election of his successor, [[Barack Obama]], and further that Obama would probably be known as the worst president in U.S. history.<ref>[http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/april/233988/Donald-Trump:-Obama-will-go-down-as-worst-president-in-U.S.-history Donald Trump: Obama will go down as worst president in U.S. history].''Bright House Networks''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref>
  â  
Trump has promoted to the [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|conspiracy theories about Obama's citizenship status]] in media appearances, and been criticized for this.<ref>{{cite news|title=Donald Trump, birther?|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0311/51473.html#ixzz1GsPWRHLL|first=Kendra|last=Marr|work=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]|date=March 17, 2011}}</ref><ref name=MacNicol>Glynnis MacNicol, [http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-birther-obama-muslim-video-2011-3 "TRUMP: Maybe Obama's Missing Birth Certificate Says He's A Muslim"], ''[[Business Insider]]'' 30 March 2011</ref> In an [[NBC-TV]] interview broadcast April 7, 2011, Trump said he was not satisfied that Obama had proven his citizenship.<ref name=WashPost4711>{{Cite news|title=Trump goes after Obama on US citizenship, says citizenship questions remain unanswered|date=April 7, 2011|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[The Washington Post]]|separator=,|postscript=|accessdate=April 7, 2011}}</ref>
Trump has promoted to the [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|conspiracy theories about Obama's citizenship status]] in media appearances, and been criticized for this.<ref>{{cite news|title=Donald Trump, birther?|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0311/51473.html#ixzz1GsPWRHLL|first=Kendra|last=Marr|work=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]|date=March 17, 2011}}</ref><ref name=MacNicol>Glynnis MacNicol, [http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-birther-obama-muslim-video-2011-3 "TRUMP: Maybe Obama's Missing Birth Certificate Says He's A Muslim"], ''[[Business Insider]]'' 30 March 2011</ref> In an [[NBC-TV]] interview broadcast April 7, 2011, Trump said he was not satisfied that Obama had proven his citizenship.<ref name=WashPost4711>{{Cite news|title=Trump goes after Obama on US citizenship, says citizenship questions remain unanswered|date=April 7, 2011|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[The Washington Post]]|separator=,|postscript=|accessdate=April 7, 2011}}</ref>
